newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: SOCCER-VENABLES WALKS INTO PAY DISPUTE IN NEW JOB.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-VENABLES WALKS INTO PAY DISPUTE IN NEW JOB.

text.p: Former England coach Terry Venables has walked into the middle of pay dispute involving senior players in his first full week in charge of Australia's national team.

The trade union representing the Australia players threatened briefly to take strike action by refusing to let the players take the field in a friendly against Norway on Saturday, Venables' third match in charge, a Soccer Australia spokesman said on Wednesday.
But the threat was quickly withdrawn after negotiations on Tuesday between Soccer Australia, the national ruling body, and the players' union, the spokesman said.
"We now have an understanding there will be no strike action affecting the match in Sydney on Saturday night," the spokesman told Reuters.

Venables, who left his job with England after guiding them to the semifinals at last year's Euro '96, took control of Australia for the first time in their 1-0 win against New Zealand in Melbourne on Saturday.
Australia, minus all their overseas-based players, including Aston Villa goalkeeper Mark Bosnich, face South Korea in Brisbane on Wednesday in their second match as host of a four-nation tournament.
The players are seeking a 75 percent share of prizemoney for international matches and 20 percent of any appearance fee paid to Soccer Australia for playing overseas.
Their claim also includes a demand for between five and 10 percent of all sponsorship, broadcasting and merchandising rights involving the national team, Soccer Australia said.
At present, the players are only paid an undisclosed match fee and daily allowance, the ruling body said.
"The players are absolutely steadfast," Australian Soccer Players' Association president Kimon Taliadoros was quoted as saying in Melbourne's The Age newspaper on Wednesday.
"They are aware of their role in as far as generating revenue for Soccer Australia is concerned and they are entitled to an appropriate share of that revenue," Taliadoros added.
Soccer Australia said further negotiations between the two sides would take place next week, several days after Australia's last game in the tournament against Norway.
Venables, the former Barcelona and Tottenham Hotspur coach, has signed an 18-month contract to guide Australia's 1998 World Cup campaign.
